Describe Mill's argument for the claim that the so-called higher pleasures are more valuable, even holding fixed intensity and duration. Describe an objection to this argument that was described in lecture.

topics: Existence precedes essence
Each person is 'condemned to be free' (be sure to understand what libertarianism is and what determinism is)
A person's essence is created by them - indeed created only by their actions - and that they are free at any time to create a different essence

Whether you are a coward or a hero is determined by what you in fact do (and not anything else, such as your intentions, your personality, your 'potential,' etc.), and is up to you to change at any time
What, on Sartre's view, constitutes commitment, e.g. to a monogamous marriage
What constitutes love, e.g. of your mother
13.full_description: Sartre Existentialism: You should know that Sartre held the following views, and be prepared to explain them: Existence precedes essence; each person is "condemned to be free" (be sure to understand what libertarianism is and what determinism is). You should know and be able to explain Sartre's view that a person's essence is created by them - indeed created only by their actions - and that they are free at any time to create a different essence. E.g. whether you are a coward or a hero is determined by what you in fact do (and not anything else, such as your intentions, your personality, your 'potential,' etc.), and is up to you to change at any time. Be prepared to discuss what, on Sartre's view, constitutes commitment, e.g. to a monogamous marriage, and what constitutes love, e.g. of your mother.

topics: The three dimensions of happiness, according to Dan Haybron

14.full_description: Dan Haybron: You should be able to state and describe the three dimensions of happiness, according to Dan Haybron. You should be able to explain what compression is and how it fits into these three dimensions. Be prepared to give examples. Which dimension is most important, according to Haybron, and why? Explain what cognitive affirmation is, and what emotional affirmation is, and whether, according to Haybron, they go together, or come apart (sometimes or always), and why. Again, be prepared to give examples.

topics: The difference between wanting and liking

What a supernormal stimulus is
At least three examples observed in non-human animals
At least two phenomena that occur in humans that might plausibly be considered supernormal stimuli
Whether these are also cases of a divergence between wanting and liking

17.full_description: Wanting vs Liking; Supernormal Stimuli: Be prepared to describe in detail what the difference is between wanting and liking, and how this manifests in the case of drug addiction, and what features of the brain underlie these different phenomena, according to current best theories in neuroscience. Be prepared to describe what a supernormal stimulus is, and give at least three examples observed in non-human animals. Be prepared to describe at least two phenomena that occur in humans that might plausibly be considered supernormal stimuli, and consider whether or not these are also cases of a divergence between wanting and liking. Consider also whether they are cases in which we want something – have an urge to do it – but indulging the urge leads to diminished well-being, or some other important loss of value, over the long term.
